properties.Name: Agua Hedionada Lagoon, CA
properties.Institute: Southern California Caulerpa Taxifolia Eradication Program
properties.Description:
In the year 2000 several populations of invasive marine algae, Caulerpa taxifolia, were found in Southern California, specifically in Huntington Beach and in Carlsbad. In Europe and Australia, releases of this species resulted in extensive populations of the seaweed destroying native communities and reducing biodiversity in both native aquatic vegetation and animal communities relying on the vegetation.  
                This project led to the successful removal of the invasive seaweed species, protecting native biodiversity and functioning ecosystems. Surveys conducted verified that the removal of the species was complete. Reducing purple urchin density in the benthic environment allows kelp forests to regrow and support fish and invertebrate communities. Currently, 46 acres of kelp forest have been restored using this method. The project has observed increasing biodiversity and biomass in kelp, invertebrate, and fish populations, as well as increases in the availability of recreational fishing targets and increased red urchin yield to fisheries.

properties.Name: Hayward - San Francisco, CA
properties.Description: Hayward Shoreline, in San Francisco’s South Bay, is made up of intertidal and subtidal mud flats. This project planted combinations of eelgrass units and different oyster substrate units to assess biological and physical effects of treatment plots. Overall, eelgrass transplanted from similar muddy conditions in Point Molate showed higher rates of success after being transplanted.

properties.Name: Mission Bay, CA
properties.Institute: Merkel & Associates, Inc; City of San Diego
properties.Description:
Mission Bay, located in San Diego, California, was once a tidal mudflat that served as an alternating endpoint of the San Diego River along with San Diego Bay. In the early 19th century, San Diego’s importance as a naval and shipping port grew, and the Army Corps of Engineers dredged out what is now Mission Bay in order to save the larger San Diego Bay from sedimentation. Mission Bay has been a recreational area since its creation, and has routine dredging to maintain the bay.
                This project attempts to mitigate negative impacts from the routine dredging by replanting eelgrass in areas where dredging has damaged the bay ecosystem. This project includes both mapping of the extent of seagrass within Mission Bay as well as the replanting of the seagrass.

properties.Name: Palos Verdes, CA
properties.Description:
For the last 100 years, kelp forests off the Palos Verdes Peninsula in Los Angeles County, California have been shrinking. Urban runoff, development, and sedimentation limits kelp growth, while overfishing reduces competition and predation of purple urchins. Purple urchins consume the kelp holdfasts at the ocean floor and create urchin barrens, destroying kelp forest and related communities that live in the kelp forests.
                This restoration project aims to reduce purple urchin density in the benthic environment, allowing kelp forests to regrow and support fish and invertebrate communities. Currently, 46 acres of kelp forest have been restored using this method. The project has observed increasing biodiversity and biomass in kelp, invertebrate, and fish populations, as well as increases in the availability of recreational fishing targets and increased red urchin yield to fisheries.

properties.Name: San Rafael - San Francisco, CA
properties.Description: San Rafael Bay, another San Francisco location, is a wide and shallow mudflat. Hydraulic mining in the 19th century caused mud to accumulate here, but the bay is slowly returning to pre-mining conditions. The sheltered nature of the bay gives a unique place for the seagrass and oyster experiment to be conducted.

properties.Name: Inland Bays, DE
properties.Description:
Rehoboth Bay in Delaware is fed by rivers that have become more and more polluted over the last half-century. Nitrogen loading has caused increasingly frequent algal blooms and contributed to the loss of seagrass beds as well as the reduction in oyster and fish population in the bay. Development has also increased exponentially along the bay in recent years.
                This project focused on the creation of two acres of eelgrass sanctuary and nursery areas. Eelgrass beds in Virginia provided the donor seeds and rhizomes for the creation of these sanctuaries. Reports estimate that a project to restore the water quality of the bay would cost up to $100 million.

properties.Name: Biscayne Bay, FL
properties.Description:
Biscayne Bay is a body of water connected to the city of Miami, Florida, and has seen over a hundred years of impacted conditions brought on by human activities. This project aimed to restore over 1140 hectares of barren sea floor with seagrass.
                This project was made up of four large scale attempts at seagrass restoration using three different species and three distinct planting techniques. All areas experienced successful growth, with restored seagrass populations spreading to previously barren areas. Animals, including both fishery and other food web species, were observed to be rapidly recolonizing the restored beds. The project estimates that about $9 million in value was restored by recovering previously unproductive bay area.

properties.Name: Tampa Bay, FL
properties.Description:
Similar to other bay areas in the United States, Tampa Bay is home to several major cities and ports. Urban development, wastewater discharge, and increasing demand for fresh water supply, as well as mechanical dredging to maintain shipping port areas all contributed to the degradation of the bay ecosystem throughout the 20th century.
                This project restored over one thousand hectares of seagrass beds thorough large-scale implementation of a water quality upgrade program. Apart from water quality upgrades, the project also directly planted seagrass using both hand and mechanical methods. Both of these programs failed without the water quality being in optimal levels. There are future plans for reconstruction of the longshore bar system as well to continue the ecological recovery of the bay ecosystem.

properties.Name: Boston Harbor, MA
properties.Description:
Boston Harbor has been a major American shipping port area for the entire history of the country. Coastal development, organic nutrient loading, and sedimentation of many areas in both the Inner and Outer Harbor areas resulted in the widespread loss of eelgrass all around the harbor.
                This project observed favorable results in seeding locations on island sites around the harbor, while the mainland areas, more connected to long term urban settlements, were generally unsuitable for seagrass restoration. This is because of sediment quality issues related to organic nutrient loading. This study also tested advantages and disadvantages relating to hand- and frame-planting techniques while transplanting seagrass.

properties.Name: Potomac River, MD
properties.Description:
Chesapeake Bay communities have been impacted by human activity since the 17th century, but the rapid urbanization of communities in the mid-20th century caused deforestation, sedimentation, and nutrient loadings. These new nutrients sponsored the growth of algae, competing with underwater vegetation including sea grass.  
                This program used a variety of planting techniques as well as large quantities of seeds to be planted. Despite early indicators of success, by the summer of 2005 almost all plants were gone, due to limited light availability and higher water temperatures than the seagrass needed.

properties.Name: Eastern Long Island Sound, NY
properties.Description: This project was designed to test the feasibility of seagrass restoration in the eastern Long Island Sound, an area that seagrass has not been able to naturally recolonize very well. Restoration activities proved that eelgrass plantings are possible and effective in establishing persistent meadows in this area.

properties.Name: Huntington Harbor, NY
properties.Institute: Town of Huntington and Cornell Cooperative Extension Marine Program
properties.Description: Restoration of eelgrass and bay scallops at several different sites in the greater Huntington Northport Bay Complex using adult shoot transplant and seeding methods to improve their survival.

properties.Name: Peconic Estuary, NY
properties.Institute: Town of Shelter Island and Cornell Cooperative Extension Marine Program
properties.Description: A GIS-based Planting Suitability Index Model was used to identify planting sites within the Peconic estuary for attempted restoration. This project involved transplanting adult shoots and using various densities to determine the most effective planting methods. They found that circular plots of 1m2 and a density of 200 shoots per m2 was the best method in these conditions.

properties.Name: Wickford Harbor, RI
properties.Institute: Save the Bay; University of Rhode Island
properties.Description:
The seagrass populations in much of the Atlantic Coast region were afflicted by a wasting disease associated with mold growth during the 1930s. In many regions the seagrass populations have not recovered. In Narragansett Bay, Rhode Island, restoration was observed until the 1960’s, when environmental degradation caused seagrass populations to drop again.
                In Wickford Harbor, the project transplanted eelgrass from an existing bed into the harbor. The purpose of this case study was not only to study transplant and restoration methodology, but also to raise public awareness for the degraded marine ecosystems. Over two thousand plants were transplanted into the harbor.

properties.Name: West Galveston Bay, TX
properties.Description:
Between 1956 and 1989, 2200 acres of healthy seagrass beds in the west Galveston Bay, Texas, were lost completely from their habitats on the barrier island edges in the bay. Dredging activities, wastewater discharge, increased urbanization, transportation, and industry contributed to the loss of the seagrass ecosystem in this location.
                Out of the two attempted transplants of seagrass, only one was deemed to be successful. Shallow and denser shoot plantings were shown to exhibit more success. The successfully transplanted shoots grew to form a new healthy bed, itself donating shoots for future restoration projects in the area.

properties.Name: Eastern Shore, VA
properties.Description:
The Atlantic side of Virginia’s Eastern Shore became a hotbed for recreational tourism in the form of hunting and fishing in the 19th century, only to see its seafood and bird harvesting yields drop precipitously by the Great Depression, mainly due to overharvesting, disease, storms, and loss of habitat. By the end of the 20th century the communities of sea grasses, shellfish like oysters and scallops, other fish, and birds had not naturally restored, making it a focal project for the Virginia Coastal Zone Management Program.
                This program aims to restore seagrass populations through transplanting seeds from healthy populations in a process called “seed broadcasting”. By 2013, over five thousand acres of seagrass beds were restored.
